questions: (1) What words refer to a direction?
(2) What words refer to facing in some direction?
(3) What words refer to a person's ability to know what direction he is going in?
(4) What words indicate that two things are going in the same direction?
(5) What words indicate that two things are going in different directions?

subdomains.name: Forward
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a forward direction.
questions: (1) What words indicate the direction forward?

subdomains.name: Backward
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a backward direction.
questions: (1) What words indicate the direction backward?

subdomains.name: Right, left
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to right and left.
questions: (1) What words refer to the right side?
(2) What words refer to the left side?
(3) What words describe a person who usually uses his right hand?
(4) What words describe a person who usually uses his left hand?

subdomains.name: Up
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the direction up.
questions: (1) What words refer to the direction up?
(2) What words describe something that is facing or pointing upwards?
(3) What words indicate that a path or road goes upward?

subdomains.name: Down
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the direction down.
questions: (1) What words refer to the direction down?

subdomains.name: Away from
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a direction away from something.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is moving away from something else?
(2) What words indicate that something moves from one place (to another place)?

subdomains.name: Towards
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a direction toward something.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is moving toward something else?
(2) What words indicate that something moves (from one place) to another place?

subdomains.name: North, south, east, west
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the directions of the compass.
questions: (1) What general words refer to a direction of the compass?
(2) What words refer to a direction of the compass?
(3) What words describe something that is toward one of the directions of the compass?
(4) What words describe something going in one of the directions?
(5) What words describe a person who is from a part of the country that is north, south, east, or west?
(6) What words refer to a compass?

subdomains.name: Be at a place
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being at a place.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something or someone is in a particular place?
(2) What words indicate that something or someone is in the correct or expected place?

subdomains.name: Absent
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being absent--to not be in a particular place, or not be in the correct or expected place.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something or someone is not in a particular place?
(2) What words refer to a person who is absent?

subdomains.name: Area
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to an area.
questions: (1) What words refer to an area?

subdomains.name: Vicinity
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to a vicinity--an area around something else.
questions: (1) What words refer to the area around something else?

subdomains.name: Occupy an area
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to occupying an area.
questions: (1) What words refer to occupying an area?

subdomains.name: Space, room
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to the amount of empty space that is available to be used.
questions: (1) What words refer to the amount of empty space that is available to be used?
(2) What words refer to providing space for someone or something?
(3) What words describe a situation where there is just enough room?

subdomains.name: Interval, space
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to an interval or space between things.
questions: (1) What words refer to the area between things?
(2) What words refer to arranging things with spaces between them?
(3) What words indicate that things have spaces between them?
(4) What words indicate that things are arranged with regular spaces in between?

subdomains.name: Spatial relations
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate a spatial relation between situations.
questions: (1) What words indicate that a situation happened at the same place as another situation?
(2) What words indicate that a situation happened at a different place as another situation?

subdomains.name: Contain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that express the idea that something contains something.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something contains something?
(2) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb 'contain' with the 'Container' in the subject position and the 'Content' in the object position.

(3) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a clause using the verb with the 'Container' in the subject position, the 'Content' in the object position, and the 'Container' in a preposition phrase marked by 'in'.
(4) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the 'Container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.
(5) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'container' as the head and the 'Content' marked by 'of'.
(6) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a noun phrase with the word 'contents' as the head and the 'Container' marked by 'of'.
(7) In English 'Containership' can be expressed by a possession phrase with the 'Container' in the first position and the word 'contents' in the second position.

subdomains.name: Parts of things
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that refer to a part of something. These words are often based on the parts of a person's body.
questions: (1) What general words refer to a part of something?
(2) If something has two sides, what words refer to the other side?
(3) What words refer to the part of something used to hold it?
(4) What words refer to the main part of something?
(5) What words refer to something added to the main part?
(6) What words refer to a layer of something?
(7) What other words refer to a part of something?

subdomains.name: Front
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the front part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the front of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the front?

subdomains.name: Back
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the back part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the back of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the back?

subdomains.name: Top
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the top part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the top of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the top?

subdomains.name: Bottom
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the bottom part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the bottom of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the bottom?

subdomains.name: Side
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the side part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the side of something?
(2) What words refer to an area that is on one side of a border or wall
(3) What words describe something that is on the side?

subdomains.name: Inner part
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the inside part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the inside part of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the inside?

subdomains.name: Outer part
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the outside or surface part of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the outside part of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the outside?

subdomains.name: Middle
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the middle part or center of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the middle part of something?
(2) What words describe something that is in the middle?
(3) What words indicate that something is in the middle of a thing or area?
(4) What words refer to the middle position between two places, times, or amounts?

subdomains.name: Edge
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the edge of something--the part of something where two sides come together.
questions: (1) What words refer to the edge of something?
(2) What words refer to the edge of an area of land?
(3) What words refer to the edge of a cup or plate?
(4) What words refer to the edge of a piece of clothing?
(5) What words refer to something put along the edge of something?
(6) What words describe something that is on the edge?
(7) What words refer to the corner of something?
(8) What words describe something that is on the corner?

subdomains.name: End, point
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to the end of something.
questions: (1) What words refer to the end of something?
(2) What words describe something that is on the end?

name: Grammar
description: Use this domain for technical linguistic terms that refer to grammatical words and constructions. Most languages have few if any words in this domain.
questions: (1) What words refer to the study of grammar?
(2) What words refer to types of grammatical words?
(3) What words refer to types of grammatical constructions?
(4) What words refer to parts of words?
(5) What words are used to talk about grammar?
(6) What words are used to talk about the sounds of a language?

subdomains.name: General words
subdomains.description: Use the following section for words that don't belong in any other domain because they are so general in meaning that you can use them to talk about any topic. Use this domain for general and indefinite words that can be used in the place of any word. Some languages have a general word that can replace a noun or a verb. For instance some Philippine languages use the word 'kwan' in this way. Colloquial German can use the word 'dings' as a noun or verb. Often these words are used when you can't remember the particular word you are trying to think of. In English we use the word 'blank' when we don't want to say a word, for instance when we are testing someone and want them to say the word.
questions: (1) What words can be used in the place of any word?

subdomains.name: Be
subdomains.description: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'be' may be used to identify something, describe something, and many other ideas.
questions: (1) What words refer to something being something?
(2) What words indicate that something is being identified?
(3) What words indicate that a group of things is something?

subdomains.name: Exist
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something exists.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate that something exists?
(2) What words refer to something starting to exist?
(3) What words refer to continuing to exist?
(4) What words refer to something ceasing to exist?
(5) What words refer to not existing?

subdomains.name: Become, change state
subdomains.description: Many languages have general words that indicate some kind of change of state. These general words may be used with a wide variety of specific meanings. For instance in English the word 'become' may be used to a change in identity, a change in characteristic, a change in nature, and many other ideas.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate a change of state?
(2) What words are used of causing or producing a state?
(3) What words are used of attaining a state?

subdomains.name: Have, of
subdomains.description: Many languages have several general words that are used to indicate a variety of relationships between two things. There are three such words in English: "have," "of," and the possessive suffix "-'s." The basic meaning of these words in English is 'to own', but they can mean many other things too. For instance they can mean that I am related to someone (I have a brother), something has a part (birds have wings), and many other ideas. There is also a set of pronouns in English that are like nouns ending in -'s (my/mine, your/yours, his, her/hers, its, our/ours, their/theirs, whose). Use this domain for these general words.
questions: (1) What general words relate two nouns?

subdomains.name: Attribution
subdomains.description: Attributes often belong to a class of attributes (shape = straight, curved) or to a scale (length = long, short). The class or scale can sometimes be included in the expression, but does not mark the proposition itself. (The towel <feels> damp. The box <weighs> five kilos.)
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate an attribute of something?
(2) What words indicate a point on a scale?
(3) What words indicate an evaluation of something?

subdomains.name: Do
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general verbs with a volitional subject (agent).
questions: (1) What general words refer to someone doing something?
(2) What words refer to the thing that is done?
(3) What words refer to the person doing something?
(4) What words describe someone who is doing something?
(5) How do you ask someone what he is doing?

subdomains.name: Happen
subdomains.description: Use this domain for non-volitional pro-verbs.
questions: (1) What words refer to something happening?
(2) What words refer to something that has happened?

subdomains.name: React, respond
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to reacting or responding to something.
questions: (1) What words refer to reacting or responding?
(2) What words refer to reacting to someone in the same way they treat you?
(3) What words refer to reacting too strongly?
(4) What words refer to how someone reacts?
(5) What words refer to the ability to react quickly to something?
(6) What words refer to reacting in a good way?

subdomains.name: Create
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to creating something--causing something to be that did not exist before.
questions: (1) What words refer to inventing something?
(2) What words refer to something that has been invented?
(3) What words refer to something that has been created?
(4) What words refer to a person who creates?
(5) What words describe something that was created?

subdomains.name: Design
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to designing something--to decide and plan how something new will look and work.
questions: (1) What words refer to designing something?
(2) What words refer to the way something is designed?
(3) What words refer to someone who designs things?

subdomains.name: Make
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to making something--joining things together to create something to be that did not exist before.
questions: (1) What words refer to making something?
(2) What words refer to something that has been made?
(3) What words refer to a person who makes something?
(4) What words describe something that was made?

subdomains.name: Change something
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to someone changing something.
questions: (1) What words are used to refer to changing something?
(2) What words refer to a person who changes something?
(3) What words describe something that can be changed?
(4) What words describe a big change?
(5) What words describe a small change?
(6) What words describe a quick change?
(7) What words describe a slow change?

subdomains.name: Event propositions
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate event propositions. Event propositions are similar in that they are normally expressed by a subject and a verb, possibly including an object, indirect object, or complement clause. However there are multiple ways in which a language can express an event, such as a passive construction, noun phrase, or subordinate clause. In addition each event type is different in its primary cases, and in the ways those cases are marked. Each event type has subtypes, such as intransitive, transitive, and bitransitive verbs. A great deal of research is needed in order to identify all the variations. Ultimately every verb must be investigated to determine how it behaves in each syntactic construction and how its case relations are marked. No two verbs are entirely alike.
questions: (1) What words indicate an event?

subdomains.name: Thing
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general words referring to things.
questions: (1) What general words refer to a thing?
(2) What words refer to a group of things of different types?
(3) What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called?
(4) What words are used to end a list of things to indicate that there are more things in the list?

subdomains.name: Physical, non-physical
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words describing something that is physical--that you can touch and see, and for words describing something that is non-physical--that you cannot touch or see.
questions: (1) What words describe something that is physical?
(2) What words refer to something that is physical?
(3) What words describe something that is non-physical?
(4) What words refer to something that is non-physical?

subdomains.name: Situation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a situation--a particular time and place, and the things that are true about it.
questions: (1) What words refer to the general situation that exists in a place?
(2) What words refer to a situation that affects what can happen or what people can do?
(3) What words refer to a situation that exists at some time during a larger event or process?
(4) What words refer to the true situation rather than the situation that people think exists?
(5) What words refer to the situation a person is in?
(6) What words indicate that something must happen or cannot happen because of the situation?

subdomains.name: General adjectives
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general adjectives that can replace or stand for a specific adjective.
questions: (1) What general words can replace an adjective?
(2) What question words ask for an adjective in the answer?
(3) What question words ask for an ad-adjective in the answer?

subdomains.name: General adverbs
subdomains.description: Use this domain for general adverbs that can replace or stand for other adverbs.
questions: (1) What general words can replace an adverb?

subdomains.name: Part of speech
subdomains.description: This domain is for organization purposes and should not be used for any words. Use the domains in this section for words that belong to a particular part of speech. It is best not to use these domains, since they are based on grammar and not meaning. But if you have a small group of words that belong to a part of speech and you want to list them all, you can use these domains. You can also classify words in this section if you don't know what they mean yet.

subdomains.name: Adjectives
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all adjectives. If there are many adjectives in your language, you should not try to list them all here. If you want to find all the adjectives, most dictionary programs can sort your dictionary by part of speech. However if your language only has a few adjectives, you can list them all in this domain. In the book, "Where Have All the Adjectives Gone?" R. M. W. Dixon [Dixon, R. M. W. 1982. Where have all the adjectives gone? Berlin: Mouton.] identifies seven universal semantic types that are often expressed by adjectives. They are: Age (new, young, old), Dimension (big, little, long, short, wide, narrow, thick, fat, thin), Value (good, bad, proper, perfect, excellent, fine, delicious, atrocious, poor), Color (black, white, red), Human propensity (jealous, happy, kind, clever, generous, cruel, rude, proud, wicked), Physical property (hard, soft, heavy, light, rough, smooth, hot, cold, sweet, sour), Speed (fast, slow). Words in the Human propensity class may be nouns. Words in the Physical property and Speed classes may be verbs.
questions: (1) What are the adjectives in your language?

subdomains.name: Adverbs
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all adverbs. If there are many adverbs in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.
questions: (1) What adverbs are in your language?

subdomains.name: Pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for the personal pronouns, including independent, subject, object, and possessive pronouns. It is best to collect all the pronouns in a chart. This way you are more certain of collecting them all and seeing how they are related to each other. A language may have more sets and more distinctions than English does, or it may have less. For instance some languages have a pronoun 'we' which includes the hearer, and another pronoun 'we' which excludes the hearer. Other languages have an indefinite pronoun that means something like the English word 'someone'. Many languages do not have the masculine (he), feminine (she), and neuter (it) distinctions that English has. It is necessary to determine the sets and functions of the pronouns for each language.
questions: (1) What general words refer to the class of pronouns?
(2) What pronouns refer to the speaker?
(3) What pronouns refer to the speaker and those associated with the speaker?
(4) What pronouns refer to the audience?
(5) What pronouns refer to the people or things being spoken about?
(6) What pronouns are used for the subject of a sentence?
(7) What pronouns are used for the object of a sentence?
(8) What pronouns are used in a possessive phrase?
(9) What pronouns are used in a possessive clause?
(10) What pronouns are used to emphasize the people or things being spoken about, especially when you are emphasizing that one person does something and not someone else?

subdomains.name: Reflexive pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns that refer back to the subject of the sentence. These pronouns should be added to the chart of personal pronouns.
questions: (1) What pronouns express reflexive reference?
(2) What pronouns express reciprocal reference?

subdomains.name: Indefinite pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns that do not refer to a definite person or thing, but can refer to anyone or anything. Some languages will not have all the sets of pronouns described below. Add each set you find in your language to the pronoun chart.
questions: (1) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a person?
(2) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a thing?
(3) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a time?
(4) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a place?
(5) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a reason?
(6) What pronouns express indefinite reference of a manner?
(7) What pronouns express indefinite reference of an amount?

subdomains.name: Relative pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns used in relative clauses.
questions: (1) What pronouns are used in relative clauses?

subdomains.name: Question words
subdomains.description: Use this domain for pronouns used in questions.
questions: (1) What pronouns are used in questions?

subdomains.name: Demonstrative pronouns
subdomains.description: Use this domain for demonstrative pronouns.
questions: (1) What pronouns are used to indicate a particular referent?

subdomains.name: Personally
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone does something himself, rather than through someone else.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate that you do something yourself, rather than through someone else?
(2) What words are used to indicate that you make something yourself rather than using a machine?

subdomains.name: Prepositions, postpositions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all prepositions and postpositions.
questions: (1) What prepositions are in your language?

subdomains.name: Conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all conjunctions.
questions: (1) What conjunctions are in your language?

subdomains.name: Phrase conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all phrase level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two words within a phrase.
questions: (1) What conjunctions join two words within a phrase?

subdomains.name: Clause conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all clause level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two clauses.
questions: (1) What conjunctions join two clauses?

subdomains.name: Sentence conjunctions
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all sentence level conjunctions--conjunctions that join two sentences.
questions: (1) What conjunctions join two sentences?

subdomains.name: Particles
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all particles.
questions: (1) What particles are in your language?

subdomains.name: Classifiers
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all classifiers.
questions: (1) What words indicate the class of something?

subdomains.name: Interjections
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all interjections.
questions: (1) What interjections are in your language?

subdomains.name: Idiophones
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all idiophones. If there are many idiophones in your language, it is probably not worth the trouble to list them here. The Shoebox program (and other dictionary programs) can sort your dictionary by part of speech.
questions: (1) What idiophones are in your language?

subdomains.name: Affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all affixes that do not fit in any of the subdomains under it. This section should be filled out by a linguist.
questions: (1) What affixes are in your language?

subdomains.name: Verb affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all verb affixes.
questions: (1) What affixes can be joined to verbs?

subdomains.name: Noun affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all noun affixes.
questions: (1) What affixes can be joined to nouns?

subdomains.name: Derivational affixes
subdomains.description: Use this domain to list all derivational affixes. A derivational affix is joined to a root and changes it into a different word. Derivational affixes often change the root into a different part of speech. Adding a derivational affix usually changes the meaning of the root in a significant way.
questions: (1) What derivational affixes are there?

subdomains.name: Very
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that intensify an attribute.
questions: (1) What words intensify an attribute?
(2) What words intensify an attribute to an extreme degree?
(3) What words indicate that an attribute is not intense?

subdomains.name: Degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate a degree on a scale.
questions: (1) What words refer to the degree of something?
(2) What words indicate a degree on a scale?
(3) What words refer to a marked extent?
(4) What words refer to a change in degree?
(5) What words express a comparative degree?
(6) What words express a superlative degree?

subdomains.name: To a large degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a large degree.
questions: (1) What words indicate a large degree?
(2) What words refer to a large degree?

subdomains.name: To a small degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a small degree.
questions: (1) What words indicate a small degree?

subdomains.name: To a larger degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a larger degree.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming larger in degree?
(2) What words refer to the amount by which something became larger?
(3) What words refer to causing something to become larger in degree?
(4) What words indicate that something is larger than another thing in degree?

subdomains.name: To a smaller degree
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a smaller degree.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is becoming smaller in degree?
(2) What words refer to the amount by which something became smaller?
(3) What words refer to causing something to become smaller in degree?
(4) What words indicate that something is smaller than another thing in degree?

subdomains.name: Completely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is done to a complete degree?
(2) What general words refer to all of something's attributes or manners?
(3) What words describe something that is done completely?

subdomains.name: Partly
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words referring to a complete degree--when something is done, happens, is thought, is felt, etc completely and in every way.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is done partly?
(2) What words indicate that something is done one part at a time?

subdomains.name: Do intensely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating intensity of an action.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate that something is being done intensely?

subdomains.name: Attribution of an attribute
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that modify an attribute.
questions: (1) What words modify an attribute?

subdomains.name: Semantic constituents related to verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that modify verbs.

subdomains.name: Tense and aspect
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense and aspect.

subdomains.name: Tense
subdomains.description: Use this domain for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate tense (also known as temporal deixis)--the time of a situation (event, activity, or state) in relation to a reference point, which is usually the time of utterance. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) present: the situation occurs simultaneously with the moment of speech.
(2) past: the situation occurred before the moment of speech.
(3) future: the situation takes place after the moment of speech; the speaker predicts that the situation in the proposition will hold.
(4) crastinal: tomorrow.
(5) hesternal: yesterday.
(6) hodiernal: today, normally with past.
(7) pre-hodiernal: before today.
(8) post-crastinal: after tomorrow.
(9) ancient past: used for narrating events in ancient or mythical time.
(10) remote: combines with other tense labels to indicate a situation occurring temporally distant from the moment of speech.
(11) immediate: a meaning label that may be combined with other tense labels to indicate a situation not simultaneous with the moment of speech, but very close to it.
(12) immediate future: what is about to occur.
(13) immediate past: occurring immediately before the moment of speech. Also called the Recent Past. Do not use this label if there is any sense of current relevance--use anterior for that.
(14) Immediate may also be combined with anterior or imperative.
(15) expected future: the situation is to occur in the near future; what is scheduled to happen.
(16) narrative time: the use of a form with no other past uses for reporting a past narrative.

(17) gnomic present: the situation described in the proposition is generic; the predicate has held, holds, and will hold for the class of entities named by the subject, such as 'Elephants have trunks'.
(18) What general words refer to the tense of an event?
(19) What words are used to indicate the present tense?
(20) What words are used to indicate the past tense?
(21) What words are used to indicate the future tense?

subdomains.name: Aspect--dynamic verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of dynamic verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) habitual: the situation is customary or usual, repeated on different occasion over a period of time. English 'used to' is past habitual; English 'Nancy sings' is present habitual.

(2) continuous: a single situation is viewed as in progress, as maintained over a period of time; also called "durative." The English "Progressive" is a continuous restricted to dynamic words. English 'I am reading; *I am knowing the number'.
(3) continuative: keep on doing what is being done. Restricted to dynamic words.

(4) progressive: the action takes place simultaneously with the moment of reference, 'to be in the process of...'. This is more restricted than the English Progressive, which may be used for events that are not actually in progress at reference time: 'I am writing a book' may be used even if the speaker is not at that moment writing.
(5) excessive duration: action is extended over a long period of time, longer than normal for that action.
(6) limited duration: action performed for a relatively short or bounded period of time.
(7) iterative: the action is repeated on one occasion; usually restricted to dynamic words, often further restricted to semelfactive words.
(8) frequentative: action occurs frequently, not necessarily habitually, nor necessarily on one occasion, as is the iterative.
(9) imperfective: the situation is viewed as unbounded in the sense that it is habitual, continuous, progressive, or iterative.
(10) perfective: the situation is viewed as bounded temporally. It cannot be simultaneous with the moment of speech; in the non-past it is sometimes interpreted as future.
(11) completive: to do something thoroughly and to completion, e.g. 'to shoot someone dead, to eat up'.
(12) inceptive: the action or event begins. We are distinguishing this from the beginning of a state.
(13) delimited: action is performed only a little.
(14) The preceding terms or "Aspects" are not usually relevant to stative words.
(15) What general words refer to an aspect of an event?
(16) What words are used to indicate that something has begun?
(17) What do people say when they want someone else to start?
(18) What is a person called who starts something?
(19) What words are used to indicate that someone is attempting to do something?
(20) What words are used to indicate that something is being done quickly?
(21) What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly?
(22) What words are used to indicate something is continuing?
(23) What words are used to indicate that something has been completed?

subdomains.name: Aspect--stative verbs
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate aspects of stative verbs. Aspects describe the temporal contours of a situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) state exists: the state is begun before reference time and continues after reference time.

(2) state commences: beginning of a state of "becoming." Often called Inceptive or Inchoative. If there is a morpheme specifically for this meaning, it is usually derivational and restricted to stative words. However, it is also possible for "Perfects" or "Perfectives" to have this as their use with stative words.
(3) state ends: state existed in the past, but no longer exists. Also a possible meaning of "Perfects" or "Perfectives" in combination with stative words.
(4) state continues: state is continuing a reference time.
(5) state changes: (self-explanatory).

subdomains.name: Relational tenses
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate relational tenses. Relational tenses describe situations where the reference time is not the same as the moment of speech. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) resulting state (resultative): action in the past produces a state that persists into the present.
(2) anterior continuing: past action continues into the present: 'I have waited over an hour' ( = and I'm still waiting).

(3) anterior: the situation occurs prior to reference time, and is relevant to the situation at reference time. This is different from a simple past or perfective, where the situation is reported for its own sake and independent of its relevance to any other situation.
(4) A form that signals a situation that is prior to and relevant to a past reference time will be coded with two meaning labels, past and anterior.

subdomains.name: Agent-oriented modalities
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate agent-oriented modalities. Agent-oriented modalities describe internal or external conditions on a willful agent with respect to the completion of the predicate situation. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) ability: the agent of the verb has the mental or physical ability to complete the action of the main verb.
(2) ability, mental: English: 'Melissa can speak Dutch'.
(3) ability, physical: English: 'Hortense can swim the English Channel'.

(4) attempt: the agent attempts to complete the action specified by the predicate. Note: this has a sense of incompleteness, and I have seen authors call this "Incomplete" and gloss the examples with 'try'.
(5) desire: the agent of the verb desires or wants to complete the action of the verb.
(6) obligation: the agent is obliged to perform the action of the verb.
(7) obligation, strong: it is absolutely incumbent upon the agent to complete the action of the main verb: 'I have to mail this letter today'.
(8) obligation, weak: it is recommended that the agent complete the action of the main verb: 'Harry ought to get a haircut before meeting Sue's mother'.
(9) permission: the agent is allowed to complete the action of the main verb: 'The students may check books out for two weeks'.
(10) root possibility: it is possible for the agent to carry out the action of the main verb; i.e. s/he is able and external conditions allow it: 'You can get that kind of paper at Ulbrich's'.
(11) intention: the agent intends to carry out the action of the main verb: 'Sam's gonna take Sanskrit next semester'.

(12) andative: agent moves away from the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be going to do something'. Of course such forms are often related to the verb 'to go' and also may have uses of intention and future.
(13) venitive: the agent moves toward the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be coming to do something'. This may be related to the verb 'to come' and may have future uses as well.

subdomains.name: Can
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that someone can do something.
questions: (1) What words indicate that someone is able to do something?
(2) What words refer to the ability of someone to do something?
(3) What words indicate that someone is not able to do something?

subdomains.name: Can't
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being incapable of doing something.
questions: (1) What words describe a person's inability to do a job?
(2) What words refer to a person's inability to do a job?

subdomains.name: Necessary
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something must happen.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is necessary?
(2) What words describe something that is necessary?
(3) What words refer to something that is necessary?
(4) What words describe something that is not necessary?

subdomains.name: Moods
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate moods.

subdomains.name: Imperative
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate imperatives. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press. Use this domain for words and affixes that a speaker uses to indicate that he is making a command. English has no command word. Some languages change the form of the verb by adding an affix. Some languages have special verbs that are only or normally used as commands. Those verbs could be classified here.
questions: (1) imperative: the verb form used for direct commands in the 2nd person. If there are also 1st and 3rd person forms, the meaning can still be that of imperative, with the 1st and 3rd persons being interpreted as 'Let us, let him...', etc.
(2) optative: the proposition represents the speaker's will. Translated into English as 'May you prosper', 'May we all meet again.' with counterfactual: 'If only he had...', etc.
(3) hortative: the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(4) prohibitive: the mood for expressing negative commands. The English is 'Don't'.
(5) admonitive: the command constitutes a warning: 'you had better not...'.
(6) Meanings co-occurring with imperative:
(7) polite: a mild or polite form of command.
(8) delayed: the action of the command is to be carried out in the future rather than immediately.
(9) immediate: the action of the command is to be carried out immediately.
(10) strong: (self-explanatory).
(11) What words indicate that the sentence is a command?
(12) What affixes indicate that the sentence is a command?
(13) What words are only used in the imperative?

subdomains.name: Hortative
subdomains.description: Use this domain for ways of saying that someone should do something. If I say someone should do something, I think it is good that he does it.
questions: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
(2) What words indicate that something should be done?
(3) What words indicate that something should not be done?
(4) What words refer to something a person should do?
(5) What words describe the person who should do something?
(6) What words describe someone who does what he should?

subdomains.name: Interrogative
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he is asking a question. English has no question word, but other languages such as Japanese do.
questions: (1) What words indicate that the sentence is a question?
(2) English has an interjection that is added to a statement that has the effect of questioning something about it.

subdomains.name: Epistemic moods
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate epistemic moods. Epistemic moods have the whole proposition in their scope and indicate the degree of commitment of the speaker to the truth or future truth of the proposition. They may be combined with any of the tenses, either in the same morpheme or in combinations of morphemes. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) possibility: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is possibly true. Some markers with this meaning also indicate future time: 'He may arrive late because of the weather; It may snow again tomorrow; She could have already taken it'.

(2) probability: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is probably true. Some marker with this meaning also indicate future time. This is sometimes called the "Dubitative" in grammars: 'Paula should be home by now'.
(3) inferred certainty: the speaker infers from evidence that the proposition is true: 'They must have killed a bear here (I can see blood on the snow)'.
(4) certainty: the speaker is emphasizing that the proposition is true.
(5) uncertainty: the speaker is emphasizing that s/he doesn't know that the proposition is true.
(6) indicative: main clause mood that also appears in questions. Contrasts with subjunctive, conditional, and imperative.

subdomains.name: Certainly, definitely
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is certainly true or is certain to happen.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is certainly true?
(2) What words indicate that something will certainly happen?
(3) What words indicate that something will certainly succeed?
(4) What words refer to doing something in order to be certain that something will happen?
(5) What words indicate that something is certain to happen and nothing can be done to stop it?
(6) What words describe something that is certain?
(7) What words indicate that something is certainly not true?

subdomains.name: Sure
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to being sure that something is true.
questions: (1) What words indicate that someone is certain about something?
(2) What words refer to making someone sure about something?

subdomains.name: Probably
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is probable or likely to occur.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something will probably happen?
(2) What words indicate that something is probably true?
(3) What words indicate that something is very probably true
(4) What words indicate that something good will probably happen?
(5) What words indicate that something bad will probably happen?
(6) What words indicate that someone or something will probably be successful?
(7) What words indicate that someone will probably do something bad?
(8) What words indicate how probable it is that something will happen?
(9) What words indicate that something is possible but not very probable?
(10) What words indicate that someone or something will probably not be successful?

subdomains.name: Possible
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is possible. Maybe implies that the speaker doesn't know something.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is possible?

subdomains.name: Uncertain
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that no one is certain that something is true, or when it is impossible to be certain that something is true.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is uncertain?
(2) What words indicate that something is uncertain, but it is likely that something bad will happen?
(3) What words indicate that two things are equally possible?
(4) What words indicate that something is uncertain because people have many different opinions about it?

subdomains.name: Unsure
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words related to not feeling sure about something or someone.
questions: (1) What words refer to not being sure about something?
(2) What words refer to not being sure whether you should do something?
(3) What words refer to making someone unsure about something?

subdomains.name: Think so
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is true, but you are not completely sure about it.
questions: (1) What words indicate that you think something is true, but you are not completely sure about it?
(2) What words indicate that you think something is true, but you have no proof of it?
(3) What do you say when you think something is true, but you are not sure?

subdomains.name: Maybe
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks it is possible that something may happen or be true, but he isn't certain.
questions: (1) What words indicate that maybe something may happen or is true?
(2) What words indicate that the speaker is guessing about a number or amount, but is not certain?
(3) What words indicate that the speaker is not certain about a suggestion, plan, or idea?

subdomains.name: Seem
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something seems to be a certain way--you see (or hear) something and think something about it, but you are not sure that what you think is true.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something seems to be a certain way, but you are unsure?
(2) What words indicate that someone seems to be doing something, or something seems to be happening?
(3) What words indicate that something seems to be happening, or something seems to be true?
(4) What words describe something, such as a feeling or quality, that someone or something seems to have?
(5) What words indicate that, because something seems to be a certain way, you think something is true?
(6) What words indicate that someone or something is not what it seems to be?
(7) What words refer to what you think or feel because of what someone or something seems?
(8) What words refer to the way something seems to appear?

subdomains.name: Just, almost not
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that although something is true, it almost is not true.
questions: (1) What words indicate that although something is true, it almost is not true?
(2) What words indicate that something bad almost happened, but it did not?
(3) What words indicate that you did something, but almost didn't do it?
(4) What words indicate that you can do something, but it is difficult?
(5) What words indicate that something is a particular amount, but not much more?

subdomains.name: Don't think so, doubt it
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that you think something is unlikely to be true or to happen.
questions: (1) What words indicate that you think it is very unlikely that something is true or will happen?

subdomains.name: Impossible
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that a speaker uses to indicate that he thinks something is impossible.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something cannot be done?
(2) What words indicate that your situation makes it impossible for you to do something?
(3) What words indicate that something cannot happen?
(4) What words indicate that something is impossible to get?
(5) What words indicate that one thing makes something else impossible?
(6) What words indicate that something is impossible?

subdomains.name: Evidentials
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate evidentials. An evidential is when the speaker indicates the source of the information on which an assertion about a situation is based. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) direct evidence: the speaker claims to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify the type of sensory evidence.
(2) visual evidence: the speaker claims to have seen the situation described.
(3) auditory evidence: the speaker claims to have heard the situation described.

(4) sensory evidence: the speaker claims to have physically sensed the situation described. This can be in opposition to one or both of the above senses (i.e. any other sense), or it can indicate sensory evidence that is not further specified (i.e. any sensory evidence).
(5) indirect evidence: the speaker claims not to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify further whether the evidence is reported or simply inferred.
(6) reported evidence: the speaker claims to know of the situation described via verbal means, but does not specify whether it is second-hand, hearsay, or via folklore.
(7) second-hand evidence: the speaker claims to have heard of the situation described from someone who was a direct witness.
(8) evidence from hearsay: the speaker claims to have heard about the situation described, but not from a direct witness.
(9) evidence from folklore: the speaker claims that the situation described is part of established oral history (e.g., mythology).
(10) inferred evidence: the speaker infers the event/action, but does not specify whether the inference is based on observable results or on a purely mental process.
(11) inference from results: the speaker infers the situation described from the evidence at hand (i.e. from the observable results of the causing event/action.)
(12) inference from reasoning: the speaker infers the situation described on the basis of intuition, logic, a dream, previous experience, or some other mental construct.

subdomains.name: Evaluator
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating who is evaluating the proposition.
questions: (1) What words indicate who is evaluating the proposition?
(2) What words indicate that you heard what you are saying from someone else?

subdomains.name: Yes
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that affirm or agree with the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the affirmative.
questions: (1) What words are used to affirm the truth of something?
(2) What words are used to refer to the action of affirming the truth of something?

subdomains.name: No, not
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that negate or deny the truth of something, or that answer a yes/no question in the negative.
questions: (1) What words are used to negate the truth of something?
(2) What words are used to refer to the process of denying the truth of something?
(3) What are the noun forms of these words?

subdomains.name: Markers expecting an affirmative answer
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that an affirmative answer is expected to a question.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate that an affirmative answer is expected to a question?

subdomains.name: Markers expecting a negative answer
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that a negative answer is expected to a question.
questions: (1) What words are used to indicate that a negative answer is expected to a question?

subdomains.name: Subordinating particles
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a subordinate clause. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) subordinating: Often there are special verb forms or morphemes associated with the verb that occur obligatorily in subordinate clauses of certain types. The extent to which such morphemes can be said to have "meaning" varies, since they often co-occur with other markers of subordination. Their function is primarily to signal the type of subordinate clause.

(2) Complement clauses: A main verb may take as its direct object a clause. These are often referred to as "Noun clauses" or "Noun complements". The verb form of the subordinate clause is usually determined by the semantics of the main verb, so in this case, our meaning labels will just refer to the context. If a verb form occurs in the complements to words of thinking and believing, the meaning label will be complement to words of thinking and believing.
(3) complement to words of thinking
(4) complement to words of believing
(5) complement to words of saying
(6) complement to words of ordering (in English we use an infinitive with these words)
(7) complement to words of wanting (again in English these are done with infinitives)
(8) complement to words of emotion (surprise, regret, happiness, sadness, etc.; the complement proposition is presupposed to be true)
(9) complement to words of obligation
(10) complement to words of admonition
(11) subsequent: following a reference time in the past.
(12) subordinator: marker indicates that the verb is in a subordinate clause.

subdomains.name: Adverbial clauses
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate adverbial clauses. The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) There are a variety of adverbial clauses (other than conditional clauses) that sometimes require a special verb form. The meaning labels for these uses are coded according to the type of clause (purpose, concessive, etc.), whether any particular temporal deixis is part of the meaning, and under "co-occurrence restrictions," whether a particular conjunction is present. The types of clauses we might run into are:
(2) purpose: the clause states the purpose for which the main clause action is taking place. Often called a "final" clause: 'He was saving his money so that his son could go to college'.
(3) concessive: translated in English as 'although, even though, despite the fact that': 'She was saving her money, even though she was a wealthy woman'.

subdomains.name: Case
subdomains.description: Each verb has a set of semantic case relations. For instance in the sentence 'I gave flowers to my wife' the verb give has three case relations. 'I' is the Agent, 'flowers' is the Patient, and 'my wife is the 'Recipient'. In this sentence the only word that marks a case relation is 'to'. English often marks case relations by their position in the sentence. Some languages mark case relations by affixes, prepositions, postpositions, and sometimes special verbs. To completely describe a language, each verb must be investigated, all its case relations must be identified, and all the ways in which these relations are marked must be described. Since verbs are often unique and unpredictable in their case relations, this information should go into the dictionary. This section should be used to classify the words and affixes that are used to mark case relations. This domain should be used for technical terms that refer to case.
questions: (1) What words are used to refer to case?

subdomains.name: Primary cases
subdomains.description: Use this section for primary cases.
questions: (1) What words indicate the subject of a sentence?
(2) What words indicate the object of a sentence?
(3) What words indicate the indirect object of a sentence?

subdomains.name: Beneficiary of an event
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of an event. The sentence "John built a house for his father" is ambiguous. If the house was for his father to live in, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of a patient', meaning that the house was for the father. If, on the other hand, the father was intending to build the house to sell, but couldn't due to an injury, then "for" would mark the 'Beneficiary of an event', meaning the father benefited from the building of the house.
questions: (1) What words mark the beneficiary of an event?

subdomains.name: Instrument
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark an instrument used to do something.
questions: (1) What words mark the instrument used to do something?

subdomains.name: Means
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the means by which something is done.
questions: (1) What words indicate the means by which something is done?

subdomains.name: Way, manner
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the way or manner in which something is done.
questions: (1) What words indicate the way you do something or the way something is done?
(2) What question words ask for the manner in which something is done?
(3) What words indicate that something is done in a particular way?
(4) What words indicate the way in which something happened?

subdomains.name: Attendant circumstances
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the attendant circumstances in which something happened.
questions: (1) What words indicate attendant circumstances?

subdomains.name: Spatial location of an event
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the spatial location of an event.
questions: (1) What words indicate the location of an event?

subdomains.name: Source (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the Source (original location) of something.
questions: (1) What words indicate the Source of movement?

subdomains.name: Path (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the Path of movement.
questions: (1) What words indicate the Path of movement?

subdomains.name: Goal (of movement)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the Goal of movement.
questions: (1) What words indicate the Goal of movement?

subdomains.name: Origin (of a person)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the place where someone was born or the place where they have been living.
questions: (1) What words indicate the place where someone was born?
(2) What words refer to the place where a person is from?

subdomains.name: Semantically similar events
subdomains.description: Use this section for words that join semantically similar events into one sentence. Each sentence is actually reporting two or more situations, which may differ in one or two respects. The words to be included in these domains indicate that two situations are being reported, or mark the differences between the two situations.

subdomains.name: Together
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating when two or more people each do the same thing and do it together, or when they do it separately.
questions: (1) What words indicate that some people do something together?
(2) What words indicate that some people do something separately?

subdomains.name: With, be with
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a person who accompanied the subject of a proposition.
questions: (1) What words indicate a person who accompanied the person who is the subject of the clause?

subdomains.name: With, do with someone
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a person who does something with another person who is the subject of the sentence.
questions: (1) What words indicate someone who goes somewhere with another person?
(2) What words indicate someone who does something with another person?
(3) What words indicate someone who does something bad with another person?
(4) What words refer to someone who does something with another person?

subdomains.name: Each other
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that two or more people do something to each other.
questions: (1) What words indicate that two people do something to each other?
(2) What words describe something that people do to each other?

subdomains.name: In groups
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that the subjects of a clause do something in groups.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is done in groups?

subdomains.name: Patient-related cases
subdomains.description: Use this section for cases that bear a relationship to the 'Patient' of a proposition.

subdomains.name: Beneficiary (of a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the beneficiary of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is often expressed as the object of a sentence. In the sentence "John built a house for his parents," the house is the Patient. It is the house that benefits the parents, not the building of the house.
questions: (1) What words mark the beneficiary of a Patient?
(2) In English the Beneficiary can be the object, but many languages do not allow this.

subdomains.name: Recipient (of a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark the recipient of the Patient of an activity. The Patient is usually expressed as the object of a sentence.
questions: (1) What words mark the recipient of a patient?
(2) In English the Recipient can be the object, but many languages do not allow this.

subdomains.name: With (a patient)
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that mark a second Patient that accompanies the primary Patient of an activity. In this type of sentence there are actually two Patients, but one of them has more prominence than the other. The primary patient is usually expressed as the object of the sentence. The second Patient may be marked by an oblique case or preposition/postposition. For instance it may be conceived as accompanying the first Patient.
questions: (1) What words mark something that is used with another thing?

subdomains.name: Connected with, related
subdomains.description: Use the domains in this section for words that indicate a logical relation between two or more words or sentences. Use this domain for words that indicate an unspecified logical relation between people, things, or situations.
questions: (1) What words indicate that two things or situations are connected somehow?
(2) What words indicate that two people are connected somehow?
(3) What words indicate that two things are connected because they are similar in some way?
(4) What words indicate that several things are connected somehow?
(5) What words refer to showing that there is a connection between two things?
(6) What words refer to something that connects two things?
(7) What words indicate that there is no connection between two things?
(8) What words indicate that something someone says has no connection with the topic being discussed?

subdomains.name: Coordinate relations
subdomains.description: Use this section for words indicating coordinate relations. Do not put any words in this domain. It is only for organizational purposes.

subdomains.name: And, also
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that you are adding another thought to a previous thought. Words in this domain may indicate a variety of relationships between words, phrases, clauses, or sentences. For instance the words may join two clauses that are the same except that the subjects are different, or the objects are different, or the verbs are different.
questions: (1) What words indicate that you are adding another thought to a previous one?
(2) What words indicate that you are adding something new to what you just said?
(3) What words indicate that you could add more things to the end of a list?
(4) What words indicate that you are adding another in a list of thoughts?

subdomains.name: Or, either
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating an alternative relation between two things or propositions.
questions: (1) What words indicate alternative relation?

subdomains.name: Association
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating an association between two things.
questions: (1) What words indicate association?

subdomains.name: Combinative relation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a combinative relation between two things.
questions: (1) What words indicate combinative relation?

subdomains.name: But
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a contrast between two thoughts that are different in some way.
questions: (1) What words indicate that someone wants to do something, but is not able to do it?
(2) What words indicate that something seems to be true, but is not true?
(3) What words indicate that something is true in spite of facts or problems that make it seem unlikely?
(4) What words indicate that an opinion is different than the opinion you have just given?
(5) What words indicate that something is true of one person or thing, but not true of another?
(6) What words indicate that although one person or thing is similar to another, there is a difference between them?
(7) What words indicate that something could happen, but something else prevented it from happening?
(8) What words indicate that the opposite of something is true?

subdomains.name: Except
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is an exception to a group, rule or pattern--something is true of all the things (or people) in a group, but it is not true of one thing.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is not included in a group, rule, or pattern?
(2) What words refer to something that is not included in a group?

subdomains.name: Instead
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is true of one thing (or person) instead of another thing.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is true of one thing instead of another thing?
(2) What words indicate that something is true of one person instead of another person?

subdomains.name: Dissociation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating a dissociation relation between two things or propositions.
questions: (1) What words indicate dissociation?

subdomains.name: Distribution
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that an event is distributed throughout a group, area, or time span.
questions: (1) What words indicate distribution?

subdomains.name: Equivalence
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating equivalence between two things or propositions.
questions: (1) What words indicate equivalence?

subdomains.name: Dependency relations
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is dependent on another thing.
questions: (1) What words express the fact that something is logically dependent on another?

subdomains.name: Derivation
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something derives from another thing.
questions: (1) What words express the fact that something is derived from another?

subdomains.name: Limitation of topic
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating the topic that is being talked about.
questions: (1) What words indicate the specific area or topic that is being talked about?

subdomains.name: In general
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is generally true, but not true in every case.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something is generally true?

subdomains.name: Relations involving correspondences
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating relations involving correspondences--a situation in which one thing is the same or similar in some respect to something else.
questions: (1) What words indicate that one thing corresponds to another?

subdomains.name: Basis
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the basis for another thing.
questions: (1) What words indicate that one thing is the basis for another?

subdomains.name: Cause
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that someone or something is the cause for an event or state, that one event is the cause for another event or state, or that an event or state is reasonable (having sufficient cause). For instance in the sentence, "John caused David to fall," "John caused" is an enabling proposition that brings about the primary proposition "David fell."
questions: (1) What words indicate that someone caused something to happen?
(2) What words indicate that something is the cause or reason for an event or state?
(3) What words indicate that something is reasonable?

subdomains.name: Reason
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that reason why someone does something.
questions: (1) What words reason why someone does something?
(2) What words refer to a reason that explains why something happened?

subdomains.name: Without cause
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that an event or state has no cause or reason, or is unreasonable (has insufficient cause).
questions: (1) What words indicate that something has no cause or reason?
(2) What words indicate that something is contrary to reason?
(3) What words indicate that something is self-caused?

subdomains.name: Result
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something is the result of another thing.
questions: (1) What words indicate the result of something?

subdomains.name: Without result
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no result.
questions: (1) What words indicate that something had no result?

subdomains.name: Purpose
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something was done for the purpose of another thing happening.
questions: (1) What words indicate the intended purpose of something?
(2) What words indicate that the purpose is so that something will not happen?

subdomains.name: Without purpose
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that something had no purpose.
questions: (1) What words indicate that there is no purpose to an action?

subdomains.name: Condition
subdomains.description: Use this section for verbal auxiliaries, affixes, adverbs, and particles that indicate a clause in a conditional sentence (If this is true, then that is true). The following definitions are taken from Bybee, Joan, Revere Perkins, and William Pagliuca. 1994. The evolution of grammar. Chicago and London: University of Chicago Press.
questions: (1) Conditional sentences: Conditional sentences consist of two clauses, the 'if'-clause or protasis (which is a subordinate clause) and the 'then'-clause or apodosis (which is the main clause). Both of these clauses may take special verb forms. (Interestingly enough, they sometime both take the same special verb forms.)

(2) There are at least three types of conditional sentences. (Labels, explanations, and examples from Li and Thompson 1981): [Li, Charles N., and Sandra A. Thompson. 1981. Mandarin Chinese: A functional reference grammar. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press.]
(3) reality condition: a conditional relation between two propositions referring to the so-called real world: 'If you see my sister, you will know that she is pregnant'.
(4) hypothetical: the situation is unreal or imagined, but one that could be true: 'If we moved, we could have a garden'.
(5) counterfactual: the proposition describes an unreal or imagined situation that could have been true but was not: 'If you had taken algebra, you would know this formula' (but you did not).
(6) The verb forms that occur in these sentences will be coded according to the type of sentence, and according to which clause of the sentence they occur in.
(7) Example: the English 'had' + past participle would be coded as:
(8) meaning label:  protasis
(9) meaning label: counterfactual
(10) Since the conjunction 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis, there will also be the following:
(11) Co-occurrence restriction: 'if'
(12) This indicates that a morpheme meaning 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis. If no such morpheme is necessary, then there will be no co-occurrence restriction.
(13) What words indicate the condition of a conditional sentence?

subdomains.name: Concession
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that the speaker is conceding a point in a debate.
questions: (1) What words indicate that the speaker is conceding a point?

subdomains.name: Discourse markers
subdomains.description: Use this domain for conjunctions and particles that function on the discourse level, and whose meaning and function is uncertain.
questions: (1) What discourse markers are in your language?

subdomains.name: Markers of transition
subdomains.description: Use this domain for conjunctions that simply move the discourse forward without any specific relationship indicated between what comes before and what comes after.
questions: (1) What words are used to join two clauses or sentences without specifying the relationship between them?

subdomains.name: Markers of emphasis
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that indicate that the phrase or sentence is particularly important.
questions: (1) What words indicate that a phrase or sentence is important?

subdomains.name: Prompters of attention
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that are used to get someone's attention or direct the listener's attention to something. These may use a verb meaning 'look' or 'listen'. Some may be a word specifically referring to attention. Others may be a greeting. Others may be words that refer to non-verbal communication such as clearing your throat.
questions: (1) What words are used to get someone's attention?
(2) What words are used to direct someone's attention to something?
(3) What words are used to warn someone of danger?
(4) What non-verbal means are used to get someone's attention

subdomains.name: Markers of direct address
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that the speaker uses to refer to the person he is addressing. These words are usually used when you start talking to someone, but can be used during a speech or conversation to refer to the person you are talking to.
questions: (1) What words are used when you start talking to someone?

subdomains.name: Markers of identificational and explanatory clauses
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words that begin a clause that identifies a specific case or example of what has just been said, or that explains what has just been said. Specific case: I have just mentioned a general class of things or a general idea and want to give a specific example of what I am talking about. Explanation: I have just said something and I think people might misunderstand, so I want to explain what I mean. Digression: I am talking about a particular topic, but want to say something that does not fit into my topic, so I say something that is about a different topic.
questions: (1) What words are used to identify a specific case?
(2) What words are used to introduce an example?
(3) What words are used to introduce an explanation?
(4) What words are used to introduce a conclusion?
(5) What words mark a digression?

subdomains.name: Markers of focus
subdomains.description: Use this domain for words indicating that one of several things is in focus.
questions: (1) What words focus especially on one of several things?
